content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::AbstractString)
    questions = []
    answers = []
    in_question = false
    in_answer = false

    for line in eachline(md)
        if startswith(line, "# Question")
            if in_question || in_answer
                throw(ErrorException("Unexpected `# Question` or `# Answer` encountered outside a question-answer pair."))
            end
            in_question = true
        elseif startswith(line, "# Answer")
            if !in_question
                throw(ErrorException("`# Answer` found without a matching `# Question`."))
            end
            in_answer = true
        elseif in_question
            push!(questions, strip(line))
            in_question = false
        elseif in_answer
            push!(answers, strip(line))
            in_answer = false
        end
    end

    if length(questions) != length(answers)
        throw(ErrorException("Unmatched question-answer pairs found."))
    end

    return (questions[1] => answers[1]), (questions[2:end] => answers[2:end])
end
```

This function uses `eachline` to iterate over the lines of the markdown text and keeps track of whether it is in a question or answer section. It pushes each line into separate arrays for questions and answers. After processing all the lines, it returns a tuple with two pairs: one containing the first question and its corresponding answer, and another pair containing the rest of the questions and their corresponding answers. The `strip` function is used to remove leading whitespace and newlines from each line before pushing it into the arrays.
